messageBody:
On 9/19/05, Ilja Preuss <preuss@...> wrote:
> junit@yahoogroups.com wrote:
> > ClassDefNotFoundError is thrown when a class could not be loaded
> > usually because its static initializer threw an exception.
> >
> > It's the most insidious of all Java exceptions
>
> Well, it's actually not an exception, but an error... ;)
>
> > because noone ever
> > knows what it means (we get about 3 support calls about it a day)
>
> It obviously means that not class definition for the specified classname
> could be found. How could it get more specific?

The problem is that ClassDefNotFoundError is usually (in my
experience) thrown as a result of an error in a static initializer.
After all, it found the class (which is why you haven't seen a
ClassNotFoundException), but it can't load it.

The actual cause is the first exception seen, with the subsequent
ClassDefNotFoundError exceptions just masking the issue... yet another
reason why static initializers are evil. And when it's thrown by the
error handler of the first exception...
